settings.specialized__what_content:
Hashimoto's Disease is an autoimmune disease that occurs when the immune system attacks the Thyroid Gland, causing it to produce too little thyroid hormone, resulting in a condition known as hypothyroidism. While there are other causes of Hypothyroidism, Hashimoto's Disease is the most common cause.

When the immune system attacks the thyroid gland and causes it to produce too much thyroid hormone, a number of functions in the body are affected and this results in a number of symptoms. Typically, Hashimoto's Disease affects and is diagnosed in people between the ages of 40 and 60 years old, and tends to be more common in women, though all people can be affected by this condition.

settings.heading: What is a thyroid gland and where is it located?
settings.specialized__faqs_ans: The thyroid gland is a small butterfly-shaped organ located at the base of your neck.

settings.heading: What is the Thyroid Gland Responsible for?
settings.specialized__faqs_ans:
The thyroid gland is a hormone-producing gland (producing Triiodothyronine which is also known as T3, Tetraiodothyronine which is also called thyroxine or T4, and Calcitonin) and is a part of your endocrine system. It helps regulate vital functions such as metabolism, growth, and body development and can also affect heart rate, temperature, digestive function, brain development, and more.

When you have Hashimoto's Disease your thyroid gland produces too little thyroid hormone which results in some bodily functions slowing down. This can result in a number of symptoms which we will discuss next.

settings.heading: What are the symptoms of Hashimoto's Disease?
settings.specialized__faqs_ans:
• Fatigue and exhaustion
  • Weight gain
  • Intolerance to cold
  • Dry skin
  • Brittle and/or thinning hair
  • Slowed heart rate
  • Irregular menstrual cycles and/or fertility issues

settings.heading: How is Hashimoto's Disease Treated?
settings.specialized__faqs_ans: If you and your doctor determine that you have Hashimoto's Disease then they may decide it's best to prescribe you certain medications or treatments to put the disease and its symptoms in remission. While Hashimoto's Disease is a lifelong disease, it is treatable and oftentimes the symptoms experienced can be addressed with medication.

settings.heading: Can Hashimoto's Disease Cause Hair Loss?
settings.specialized__faqs_ans:
Hashimoto's Disease can cause hair loss. Since Hashimoto's Disease slows down functions in the body, it can disturb the hair growth cycle process and result in hair thinning and loss. Fortunately, this type of hair loss is typically temporary and your normal hair cycle should resume once your Hashimoto's Disease is treated.
